source.name: reading question built-in objects
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks below.
source.text:
A <<<class>>> is the blueprint used to create object.
An <<<object>>> a version of a class used by programmers.
An object is said to be an <<<instance>>> of a class.
<<<Instantiation>>> is when an object is created from a class.
source.guidance:
A class is the blueprint used to create object.
An object a version of a class used by programmers.
An object is said to be an instance of a class.
Instantiation is when an object is created from a class.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define class, object, instance, and instantiation

text:
is the blueprint used to create object.
An

a version of a class used by programmers.
An object is said to be an
is when an object is created from a class.

source.name: reading question user-define objects
source.guidance:
When instantiating an object, you start by giving the object a type. In this case, the type is `Pitcher`. Give the object a name followed by the assignment operator. Use the `new` keyword and the class name to create a new object of type `Pitcher`.

```java
Pitcher pedro = new Pitcher();
```

To access a class attribute, use dot notation. That means using the object's name (`pedro`) followed by a `.`, and the use the name of the attribute. Assign the value `2.93` to the attribute like you would a variable.

```java
pedro.era = 2.93;
```
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify how to instantiate an object and modify an attribute

source.name: the constructor reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Which code snippet below would be the constructor for the `Dog` class?
source.guidance:
In Java, the constructor uses the name of the class (capitalization must match) and a set of parentheses. Since the class is `Dog`, the constructor would be:

```java
Dog()
```

The constructor does not use the keyword `class`. In addition, the spelling of the constructor must match that of the class. Since the class starts with a `D`, so must the constructor.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the constructor

source.name: constructor and parameters reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Assume the following object instantiation:

```java
Person p = new Person(18, "Dallas");
```

Which code snippet below represents the constructor needed for this instantiation?
source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```java
Person(int age, String homeTown)
```

Each parameter for the constructor requires a type. In addition, the order of the parameters is important. Since the object instantiation had `18` before `"Dallas"`, the constructor must do the same.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the constructor based on object instatiation

source.name: reading question class attributes
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks below.
source.text:
A <<<class>>> attribute is an attribute whose value is shared by all instances of a class.
An <<<object>>> attribute is an attribute whose value is independent of other instances of a class.
source.guidance:
A class attribute is an attribute whose value is shared by all instances of a class.
An object attribute is an attribute whose value is independent of other instances of a class.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between a class attribute and an object attribute

text:
attribute is an attribute whose value is shared by all instances of a class.
An
attribute is an attribute whose value is independent of other instances of a class.

source.name: reading question shallow vs deep copy
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks below.
source.text:
A <<<deep>>> copy is when Java makes a copy of the object and its attributes.
A <<<shallow>>> copy is when Java makes a copy of the object, but the attributes are shared.
source.guidance:
A deep copy is when Java makes a copy of the object and its attributes.
A shallow copy is when Java makes a copy of the object, but the attributes are shared.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between shallow and deep copies

text:
copy is when Java makes a copy of the object and its attributes.
A
copy is when Java makes a copy of the object, but the attributes are shared.

source.name: introduction to objects formative assessment 1
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Assume the following code:

```java
Dog fido = new Dog();
fido.breed = "poodle";
```

Rearrange the code blocks below to declare the `Dog` class that corresponds to the code above. **Note**, not all of the code blocks will be used.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT declare a class

source.name: introduction to objects formative assessment 2
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Select **all** of the statements that are true about shallow and deep copies.

answers.answer: You need to use the copy constructor to make a deep copy
Shallow copies only copy the object but not the object attributes
Deep copies make a copy of the object and the object attributes
Changing an attribute of one shallow copy will affect the attribute of the other shallow copy

source.guidance:
All of the statements are true. 
* The copy constructor is used to make a deep copy. 
* Shallow copies only make a copy of the object, but not of the attributes.
* Deep copes make a copy of the object and the attributes.
* Changing an attribute of one shallow copy will affect the attribute of the other shallow copy.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between shallow and deep copies

source.name: intro objects lab 2 question
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

What does "instantiate an object" mean?

answers.answer: Instantiating an object means to create an object based on a class.
Instantiating an object means to create a class.
Instantiating an object means to declare a variable.
Instantiating an object means to make a copy of another object.

source.guidance: Instantiating an object means to create an object based on a class. The class is the blueprint from which objects are made. The act of creating an object based on the class blueprint is called instantiation.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define object instantiation

source.name: introduction to objects lab challenge
source.instructions: Submit your code when ready.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT make a deep copy of an object

source.name: objects lab 3 question
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

The following lines of code were used in this lab. Which line of code instantiated a `JFrame` object?
source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```java
JFrame window = new JFrame("Photogram");
```

Java uses the `new` keyword when instantiating objects.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify object instantiation

source.name: intro objects lab question 4
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

Fill in the blank below with the correct word.
source.text: The <<<static>>> keyword is used to denote a class attribute.
source.guidance: The `static` keyword is used to indicate a class attribute.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the keyword used to create class variables

text: keyword is used to denote a class attribute.

source.name: intro objects lab 5 question
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

What are instance variables?

answers.answer: Instance variables are variables created by the constructor. You can think of instance variables as the attributes of an object.
There is no such thing as an instance variables in Java.
Instance variable is another name for a global variable.
Instance variables are variables created inside methods.

source.guidance: Instance variables are variables created by the constructor. You can think of instance variables as the attributes of an object. Instance variables often store the values passed to the constructor as parameters.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define instance variable

source.name: mutability external methods reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Objects are mutable. What does this mean?

answers.answer: Mutability means that value of object attributes can be changed.
Mutability means that the you can change the attribute name for the object.
Mutability means that objects must remain the same at all times.
Mutability means that an object change one time only.

source.guidance: Object mutability is the concept that values of object attributes can be changed.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define mutability

source.name: external methods vs class methods reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks with either **external method**, **instance method**, or **external methods and instance methods** so that the sentence is correct.
source.text:
An <<<instance method>>> is declared inside of a class.
An <<<external method>>> is declared outside of a class.
<<<External methods and instance methods>>> can modify an object.
source.guidance:
The correct answers are:

An instance method is declared inside of a class.
An external method is declared outside of a class.
External methods and instance methods can modify an object.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between external and instance methods

source.name: printing the meal 1 reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

What is the name of a method that is defined within a class?
source.guidance: An instance method is a method that is defined within a class. The name `method` is not correct because it does not distinguish if the method was declared inside or outside of a class. While instance methods can be a user-defined method, not all user-defined methods are instance methods.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate a instance method from other methods

source.name: methods formative assessment 2
source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```java
myDog.bark();
```

* `bark();` is not correct because methods are called with dot notation. Dot notation requires the object name followed by the method name. This code snippet is missing the object name.
* `myDog.bark("Brutus", "Pomeranian");` is not correct because the `bark` method does not take any arguments.
* `System.out.println(myDog.bark());` is not correct because the `bark` method does not return a value that can be printed.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT demonstrate how to call an instance method

An **instance** method must instantiate an object before being called.

source.name: static methods formative assessment 2

answers.answer: Static methods are not allowed to directly access instance attributes.
The return type of the `describe` method should be `String`.
The constructor has too many parameters.
There is nothing wrong with the code.

source.guidance: Static methods are not allowed to directly access instance attributes. Either the method needs to be an instance method (remove the `static` keyword), or you need to pass a `SmartPhone` object to `describe` and access the attributes via the argument.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recognize that static methods cannot directly access instance attributes

source.name: mutability lab 3 question
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

What keyword is used when creating an instance method?

answers.answer: There is no keyword used when creating an instance method

source.guidance: There is no keyword used when creating an instance method. A static method uses the `static` keyword, but there is no keyword to designate an instance method.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the lack of keyword used to declare an instance method.

source.name: what is encapsulation reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Select the **best** definition of encapsulation from the choices below.

answers.answer: Encapsulation occurs when you group together related data and methods, and when you hide or restrict access to data.
Encapsulation occurs when you hide or restrict access to data.
Encapsulation occurs when you group together related data and methods.

source.guidance: There are two main ideas behind encapsulation: grouping together related data and restricting this data. Each idea on its own can be an example of encapsulation. However, the best definition is one that includes grouping the data and restricting the data.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define encapsulation

source.name: public access modifier reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Using the ideas of encapsulation, select **all** the parts of your program that should use the `public` access modifier.
source.guidance: Constructors and methods should make use of the `public` access modifier. Not every method will be public, but encapsulation requires that some methods be public. As a general rule, all attributes should be private even though Java allows for public attributes.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify what parts of their program should be public.

source.name: private access modifier reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Select **all** of the true statements.

answers.answer: Some methods should be private while others public
It is impossible to access private attributes and methods
Methods called by the user should be private

source.guidance:
## True Statements
* The statement `All attributes should be private` is true because encapsulation dictates that access to attributes should be restricted.
* The statement `Some methods should be private while others public` is true because encapsulation says to restrict access with private methods. However, if all methods are private then the user could not call them. Therefore you need a mix of private and public methods.

## False Statements
* The statement `It is impossible to access private attributes and methods` is false because public methods can invoke private attributes and methods.
* The statement `Methods called by the user should be private` is false because methods called by the user need to be public.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recognize true statements about the private access modifier

source.name: black box reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Which definition below is the **best** definition for code as a black box?

answers.answer: When users know how to interact with the code, but they do not understand the inner workings of the code.
When users do not understand the inner workings of the code.
When the `private` access modifier is used.

source.guidance:
The best definition is:

> When users know how to interact with the code, but they do not understand the inner workings of the code.

A key part of code as a black box is that users do not need to understand the inner workings of the code. However, users are expected to use black box code, so they need to understand how to interact with it. While the `private` keyword is used to hide code from the user, simply using `private` does not create a black box. A black box is the result of careful planning  hiding everything that should not be directly accessed while making certain methods public.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define black box code

source.name: encapsulation formative assessment 1

answers.answer: Everything is private. There is no way to instantiate a `Dog` object or call the `bark` method.
Trick question, there is nothing wrong with the code.
The instance attributes should be public.

source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

>Everything is private. There is no way to instantiate a `Dog` object or call the `bark` method.

Encapsulation is the practice of hiding and exposing information to the user. As written, the `Dog` class cannot be instantiated because the constructor is private. Even if this were public, the user could not call the `bark` method. Encapsulation means using both the `public` and `private` access modifiers.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify incorrect encapsulation

source.name: encapsulation formative assessment 2
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Encapsulation requires the use of the `public` and `private` keywords. Fill in the blanks so that the proper access modifier(s) correspond to different parts of a program.
source.text:
The constructor should be <<<public>>>.
Instance attributes should be <<<private>>>.
Methods should be <<<public and private>>>.
source.guidance:
Here are the correct answers:

* Constructors should be public. If not, you cannot instantiate an object.
* The convention in Java is to always make instance attributes private.
* Methods need to be both public and private. Only those methods need by the user should be public; the rest should be private.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify when the public and private access modifiers should be used

source.name: getters reading question
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create a getter method

source.name: setters reading question
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create a setter method

source.name: data validation reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Select **all** of the true statements about data validation.

answers.answer: Data validation is done in a setter method
Data validation is important because the Java compiler cannot find all errors
Data validation is done in a getter method
Data validation is important because you want to make sure values of the wrong data type are not assigned to an attribute

source.guidance:
The true statements are:

>Data validation is done in a setter method
Data validation is important because the Java compiler cannot find all errors

* The job of a getter method is to return the value of an attribute. These methods should never update the value of an attribute, so data validation should not be done in a getter method.
* The Java compiler will find some kinds of errors like incorrect data types. However, the compiler does not understand the context of the code. Data validation is the process of making sure a value is appropriate for its intended use.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify true statements about data validation

source.name: getters and setters formative assessment 1
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Fill in the blanks below.
source.text:
A <<<getter>>> accesses the value of a private instance variable.
A <<<setter>>> mutates the value of a private instance variable.
source.guidance:
A **getter** accesses the value of a private instance variable.
A **setter** mutates the value of a private instance variable.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define getters and setters

text:
accesses the value of a private instance variable.
A
mutates the value of a private instance variable.

source.name: getters and setters formative assessment 2
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT construct a setter with data validation

source.name: encapsulation lab 1 question
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

Fill in the blanks below with the appropriate access modifier.
source.text:
The <<<private>>> access modifier means that an instance cannot directly access an attribute or method.
The <<<public>>> access modifier means that an instance can directly access an attribute or method.
The <<<default>>> access modifier is assumed when no modifier is used before an attribute or method.
source.guidance:
* The `private` access modifier means an instance cannot directly access an attribute or method. Instead, you have to use a public method (like a getter or a setter) to access private attributes or private methods.
* The `public` access modifier means that an instance can directly access or modify the attribute or method.
* If you do not use an access modifier, Java assumes the `default` access modifier, which is similar to `public`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define public, private, and default access modifiers

text:
access modifier means that an instance cannot directly access an attribute or method.
The

access modifier means that an instance can directly access an attribute or method.
The
access modifier is assumed when no modifier is used before an attribute or method.

source.name: encapsulation lab 2 question

answers.answer: Error message, `color` is a private attribute.

source.guidance: The `color` attribute is private which means an instance cannot access or modify it. Java would throw an error message.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT predict output from code

source.name: encapsulation lab 3 question

answers.answer: The setter method only works with integers
The setter method only works with even numbers
The setter method only works with doubles
The setter method only works with odd numbers

source.guidance:
The correct answers are:

```
The setter method only works with integers
The setter method only works with even numbers
```

The method header for `setAttribute` requires that an integer be passed to the method. It does not work with any other data type. The `%` operator is modulus which returns the remainder from `newNumber` and `2`. If the parameter is even (no remainder when divided by 2) then the `number` attribute will take a new value.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT understand how data is being validated

source.name: encapsulation lab 4 question

answers.answer: Error message, the getter and setter should be called `getColor` and `setColor`.

source.guidance: The code will print `blue`. The convention is to name the getter and setter `getColor` and `setColor`. However, Java will not throw an error message if this convention is ignored.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify naming conventions for getters and setters

Drag the code blocks into the box below to create a static method called `addition`. This method accepts two integer parameters (`num1` and `num2`) and returns the sum of these two parameters. **Note**, not all of the code blocks will be used, and code blocks must be properly indented.

source.name: what is inheritance reading question
source.guidance:
The correct answers are:
* `ABC` is the subclass
* `XYZ` is the superclass

Because the definition of `ABC` contains `extends XYZ`, `ABC` is the subclass. That means `XYZ` must be the superclass.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT distinguish between the superclass and the subclass

source.name: super keyword reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

What does the keyword `super` refer to?
source.guidance: The keyword `super` refers to the superclass, which is sometimes called the parent class. For example, calling `super` in the constructor of the subclass will call the constructor of the superclass.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify to what the super keyword refers

source.name: inheritance hierarchy reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

When does the `instanceof` operator return `true`? **Hint**, there is more than one right answer.

answers.answer: When the object is an instance of the same class.
When the object is a subclass of the comparison class.
When the object is a superclass of the comparison class.

source.guidance:
The correct answers are:
* `When the object is an instance of the same class.`
* `When the object is an instance of the subclass.`

The `instanceof` operator compares an object and a class. If the object has the same type as the comparison class it returns `true`. It also returns `true` when the object is a subclass of the comparison class.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT test for inheritance hierarchy

source.name: superclass & subclass formative assessment 1
source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```java
class Dog extends Pet {}
```

Java uses the `extends` keyword to indicate inheritance.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT create a subclass

source.name: superclass & subclass formative assessment 2
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT call the constructor from the superclass with arguments

source.name: extending a class reading question
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT extend the constructor of the superclass

source.name: method overriding reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Select all of the statements that are true for method overriding and extending a class. **Hint:** there is more than one correct answer.

answers.answer: Extending a class happens when new attributes or methods are added to the subclass that do not exist in the superclass.
Method overriding happens when the subclass has a method with the same name as the superclass, but the subclass's method does something different.
Method overriding happens when new attributes or methods are added to the subclass that do not exist in the superclass.
Extending a class happens when the subclass has a method with the same name as the superclass, but the subclass's method does something different.

source.guidance:
The correct answers are:

* Method overriding happens when the subclass has a method with the same name as the superclass, but the subclass's method does something different.
* Extending a class happens when new attributes or methods are added to the subclass that do not exist in the superclass.

The other two choices are incorrect because they have confused "method overriding" with the definition for "extending a class" and vice versa.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between extending a class and method overriding

source.name: Extending & Overriding Formative Assessment 1
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT extend the subclass with a new method

source.name: extending & overriding formative assessment 2
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT override a method from a superclass

source.name: overriding annotation reading question
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT annotate when overriding a method

source.name: multiple inheritance reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Why does Java not allow for multiple inheritance where two or more superclasses are of different data types?

answers.answer: This type of multiple inheritance leads to ambiguity.
This type of multiple inheritance is impossible. No programming languages allow for this type of multiple inheritance.
Trick question, this type of multiple inheritance is allowed.
This type of multiple inheritance causes a syntax error.

source.guidance: Multiple inheritance where the superclasses have different data types leads to ambiguity. Imagine that each superclass has a method with the same name. Java cannot tell which method to invoke if the subclass calls this method.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain why multiple inheritance with superclasses of different types is not allowed

source.name: substitution principle reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks below.
source.text: The substitution principle states that a substitution can be made if a <<<subclass>>> is used in place of its <<<superclass>>>.

source.name: extending and overriding multilevel inheritance reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Use the image below to help you fill in the blanks.

![Reading Question](.guides/img/inheritance/multilevel_reading_question.png)
source.text:
<<<Code sample 1>>> is an example of extending a class.
<<<Code sample 2>>> is an example of overriding a method.
source.guidance: Extending a class is when a new method is added to the subclass that is not present in either superclass. Overriding a method is when the subclass has a method that shares a name with a method from a superclass, but the subclass method performs a different task.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT differentiate between extending and overriding in multilevel inheritance

source.name: multiple inheritance hierarchy reading question
source.instructions:
Assume the following code:

```java
Bravo b = new Bravo();
Delta d = new Delta();

b.display();
d.display();
```

Which produces the following output:

```
Bravo
Alpha
Delta
Charlie
Alpha
```

Using the above information, fill in the blanks for inheritance.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT choose the proper inheritance scheme to match a given output

source.name: multiple inheritance formative assessment 1

answers.answer: Class `Foxtrot` is a superclass to `Echo` and a subclass to `Golf`.
Class `Echo` is an example of multilevel inheritance.
You can substitute class `Golf` for class `Echo`.

source.guidance:
The correct answers are:
* `Class `Foxtrot` overrides the `hello` method.` This is true because `super.hello` means another method `hello` exists in the superclass.
* `Class `Foxtrot` is a superclass to `Echo` and a subclass to `Golf`.` This is true because `Foxtrot` extends `Golf` and `Echo` extends `Foxtrot`.
* `Class `Echo` is an example of multilevel inheritance.` This is true because it inherits from `Foxtrot` who in turn inherits from `Golf`.

The substitution principle only works when you substitute a subclass for a superclass. `Golf` is a superclass to `Echno`, so the substitution does not work.

source.name: inheritance lab 1 question
source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```markdown
India
```

* `Golf` extends `India`, so it is a subclass. However, nothing extends `Golf` so it is not a superclass.
* `Hotel` does not extend any classes so it is not a subclass. `India` extends `Hotel`, so `Hotel` is a superclass.
*  `India` extends `Hotel` so it is a subclass. In addition, `Golf` extends `India` so `India` is a superclass.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify inheritance hierarchy order

source.name: inheritance lab 3 question
source.guidance: The substitution principle says that a subclass can be used in place of the superclass. Since `myMethod` has a parameter of type `A` and `B` is a subclass of `A`, an object of type `B` can be passed to `myMethod`.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT recognize the substitution principle in action

source.name: polymorphism method overriding reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Why is method overriding an example of polymorphism?

answers.answer: Method overriding has a single interface (the method name) and works with different forms (the superclass and subclass).
Method overriding has a single interface (the method name), but only works with a single data type (the subclass).
Method overriding is not an example of polymorphism, it is an example of inheritance.

source.guidance: Polymorphism occurs when there is a single interface that works with multiple forms. When overriding a method, two methods have the same name (a shared interface) and they work with different forms (the superclass and the subclass). This is why method overriding is an example of polymorphism.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain why method overriding is an example of polymorphism

source.name: polymorphism method overloading reading question

source.learningObjectives: SWBAT properly call an overloaded method

source.name: polymorphism formative assessment 1
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Mark all of the ways in which polymorphism can be implemented. **Hint**, there is more than one correct answer.
source.guidance:
The correct answers are:

```markdown
Abstract methods
Method overloading
Method overriding
```

Inheritance by itself is not a form of polymorphism. If inheritance uses method overriding, then that would be a form of polymorphism. However, you can have inheritance without method overriding, therefore inheritance is considered a form of polymorphism.

Encapsulation is about hiding and sharing information in objects. This is not a form of polymorphism.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify the different forms of polymorphism in Java

source.name: polymorphism formative assessment 2

answers.answer: Method Overriding - The subclass `Circle` creates the method `area` replaces the `area` method from the superclass.
Method Overloading - There is more than one instance of the method `area` that have different definitions (number of parameters).
Abstract Method - `Circle` extends the abstract class `Rectangle` and must define the abstract method `area`.

source.guidance:
The correct answer is **method overriding**.

* This is not method overloading because you would need the more than one method in the same class. There are two versions of `area`, but one is in the superclass and the other is in the subclass. In addition, these methods have the same definition (neither one takes a parameter).
* This is not abstract methods because `Rectangle` is not an abstract class, and the method `area` is not an abstract method.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify method overriding

source.name: polymorphism lab question 1
source.guidance: The correct answer is `Method overloading`. Neither method uses the keyword `abstract` so these are not abstract methods. These methods do not appear in a superclass and a subclass so this is not method overriding. This is method overloading because we have methods with the same name but different parameters.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify method overloading

source.name: polymorphism lab question 3
source.instructions:
## Lab Question

Fill in the blanks below with the appropriate definition for each term.
source.text:
When a subclass has a method with the same name as the superclass, but the subclass performs a different task. - <<<Method Overriding>>>
When a method performs different tasks depending on its parameters - <<<Method Overloading>>>
When a method **must** be overriden in the sublcass - <<<Abstract Method>>>
source.guidance:
**Method Overriding** - When a subclass has a method with the same name as the superclass, but the subclass performs a different task.
**Method Overloading** - When a method performs different tasks depending on its parameters.
**Abstract Method** - When a method must be overriden in the subclass.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT define different ways of incorporating polymorphism

text: When a subclass has a method with the same name as the superclass, but the subclass performs a different task. -
When a method performs different tasks depending on its parameters -
When a method **must** be overriden in the sublcass -

source.name: polymorphism lab question 4
source.guidance: The correct answer is method overloading because you have more than one method in the same class with the same name but different sets of parameters. In addition, there is no inheritance. A subclass needs to inherit from a superclass before it can override a method. Similarly, you must inherit from an abstract class before implementing an abstract method.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify method overloading

source.name: importing user-defined classes reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

How do you use a user-defined class that is in a separate file in your Java program?

answers.answer: Compile both of the Java files. These files must be in the same folder.
Compile both of the Java files. These files can be in separate folders.

source.guidance: In order to use a user-defined class in a separate file, you need to compile both the user-defined class and the main Java program. These files **must** be in the same folder.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT explain how to use user-defined classes in a separate file

source.name: composition reading question
source.instructions:
## Reading Question

Fill in the blanks below with the words from the dropdown menu.
source.text:
<<<Inheritance>>> should be used to add functionality if there is a "is a" relationship.
<<<Composition>>> should be used to add functionality if there is a "has a" relationship.
source.guidance:
Use inheritance when you have a "is a" relationship; e.g. a car is a vehicle.
Use composition when you have a "has a" relationship; e.g. a car has an engine.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT identify when to use composition and when to use inheritance

source.name: advanced topics formative assessment 1
source.instructions:
## Formative Assessment

Assume that the ArrayList `myList` is of type `myObject`. Choose the code below that would call the `go` method on the fourth element in the ArrayList.
source.guidance:
The correct answer is:

```java
myList.get(3).go();
```

ArrayLists use the `get` method as opposed to square brackets to reference an element. ArrayLists start counting elements with 0, so the fourth element would be `3`. Once you have referenced the correct element with `myList.get(3)` then add `.go()` to call the `go` method.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT call a method on an object in an ArrayList

with

source.instructions:
## Lab Question

Select all of the things that must be true in order to use a user-defined class in another file. **Hint**, there is more than one correct answer.

answers.answer: The two files have the same name.
The two files are in the same folder.

source.guidance: Both files must be in the same folder and they must both be compiled. Once this happens, Java can use a user-defined class in another file.
source.learningObjectives: SWBAT describe how Java is able to use code written in a separate file
